<a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/e-sa-5-stocks-under-50?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=5stocksunder50-50dollars&aid=9394&paid=9394&waid=9394&source=esamnbwdg0210061&psource=esamnbwdg0210061&wsource=esamnbwdg0210061" style="border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank" class=""><img alt="The Motley Fool" style="width:100%;max-width: 182px; display: inline; vertical-align: middle;" width="182" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL2NvbXBhbnkvbG9nby8xMi8xNTgxMzUxMzU2LW1vdGxleS1mb29sLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6ImNvbWV0LW1vcm5pbmdicmV3IiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0="></a>
</th>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong data-stringify-type="bold" style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>When we first watched videos of Europeans clapping on their balconies for healthcare workers, it seemed like a nice gesture...but we didn’t really think much of it.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span class="c-mrkdwn__br" data-stringify-type="paragraph-break"></span>Now, every day at 7pm New Yorkers are throwing open their windows, breaking out the pots and pans, and saluting medical professionals for their lifesaving work. It’s extremely powerful.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span class="c-mrkdwn__br" data-stringify-type="paragraph-break"></span>And now we know our wok is tuned to a B-flat.<span class="c-message__edited_label" aria-describedby="slack-kit-tooltip"> </span></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/07/world-leaders-weigh-restarting-economies?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
World Leaders Sick of Working in PJs
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Economy restart" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MTUvZWNvbm9teV9yZXN0YXJ0LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the middle of a global public health crisis, a leader’s No. 1 goal is to stop the spread of the disease. But as grisly economic numbers stack up and new data indicates infection rates may be leveling off, some governments are also looking for ways to safely restart the economic car. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Keep in mind, this is like starting a 12-year-old Jag—you have to be very, very careful. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">First, in the U.S. </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Saturday, President Trump said he may convene a second coronavirus task force that focuses on how to restart the economy. Then yesterday, top economic advisor Larry Kudlow <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/07/larry-kudlow-coronavirus-small-business-171662?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told Politico</a> the administration may reopen the economy in the next four to eight weeks. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>On Fox News, Kudlow pointed to New York, the U.S. epicenter, where some numbers show the outbreak may be turning a corner.  </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>New deaths in the state had their largest single-day increase yesterday. But infection rates and hospitalizations are hovering around the same level.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hoping to leave his PowerPoint days behind, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has gathered a group of confidants who are reportedly consulting with medical and economic experts to determine how to get New York's rusty gears turning again. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Across the Atlantic </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some Vitamin D-deprived governments in Europe are already cracking the door open. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Western Europe's biggest petroleum-producing nation, Norway, will <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-07/norway-starts-easing-restrictions-as-virus-seen-under-control?sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reopen schools</a> and universities on April 27. Service businesses that require personal contact will resume gradually. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Norway reacted to the threat of coronavirus early on, and got results. Its new infection rate peaked at 425/day, and that’s been wrestled down to just over 100.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Across the North Sea, Germany is planning <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/04/06/business/germany-coronavirus-economy/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a slow economic revival</a> that would work in tandem with measures to keep the virus from spreading. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> All of this hinges on one key variable: widely available testing, which the U.S. is still behind on. As they get people back to work, governments need the ability to ensure it’s the economy that gets restarted, not the outbreak.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we're here: </strong>Wuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus originated, is now officially <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/07/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">out of lockdown</a>. </p>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/07/wework-board-committee-sues-investor-softbank?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
SoftBank-WeWork Is the New Wilder-Fury
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A special committee of the WeWork board is <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/07/wework-sues-softbank-in-intensifying-crisis-over-canceled-3b-tender-offer/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suing SoftBank</a> for backing out of its agreement to buy up to $3 billion of WeWork stock. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> It feels like the 1830s, but in fact it was just last October when SoftBank swooped in to rescue WeWork after its spectacularly botched IPO attempt. As part of a larger rescue package, the Japanese conglomerate pledged to buy up to $3 billion in stock from existing employees and investors—including former CEO Adam Neumann. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But SoftBank did not follow through on that pledge, claiming last week that WeWork failed to meet five conditions the deal was premised on. Board rumblings of legal retaliation followed soon after.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>WeWork’s in a tough spot. Its short-term lease system means tenants can walk away at the drop of a tequila shot. And as the coronavirus strikes the economy, <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/78dbfb03-f47d-41f3-9bf6-6696e5ef626b?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">thousands reportedly are</a>, by withholding rent or ending leases.</p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HEALTHCARE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/07/trump-medical-leaders-split-hydroxychloroquine-treatment-covid19?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Trust Me, I'm Not a Doctor
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Here's a tongue twister: </strong>Say "hydroxychloroquine" three times. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Now a brain twister:</strong> President Trump and other high-ranking U.S. officials are <a href="https://apnews.com/0a5ab4f3e9340193b4c7c7c72665cd12?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">encouraging</a> doctors to use the anti-malaria drug to treat patients with COVID-19...despite warnings from medical leaders. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The drug reportedly hit the president's radar several weeks ago after a Fox News segment detailed its effectiveness in a French trial. Oracle cofounder Larry Ellison and Rudy Giuliani both pushed the president to advocate for hydroxychloroquine, and Giuliani has aggressively championed the drug. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Many are skeptical.</strong> Infectious disease expert Dr. Anthony Fauci said it's only supported by <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/06/us/politics/coronavirus-trump-malaria-drug.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">anecdotal findings</a>. The American Medical Association’s president said she wouldn't prescribe it over concerns of severe side effects.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The sudden spike in demand is raising <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/07/patients-with-autoimmune-diseases-running-out-of-hydroxychloroquine.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">supply concerns</a>, especially among patients who take it for autoimmune conditions like lupus and arthritis. Yesterday, India <a href="https://fortune.com/2020/04/07/coronavirus-hydroxychloroquine-trump-india-china/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">eased a ban</a> on foreign exports of the drug after President Trump threatened to retaliate. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead…</strong>some doctors are already prescribing COVID-19 patients hydroxychloroquine after the FDA authorized emergency use of the drug last week. Desperate for anything to reduce America's 380,000+ cases, Trump mused Sunday, "What do you have to lose?"</p>

<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The coronavirus crisis will eliminate 6.7% of working hours globally this quarter, the UN's International Labour Organization (ILO) <a href="https://www.ilo.org/global/about-the-ilo/newsroom/news/WCMS_740893/lang--en/index.htm?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">projects</a>. That’s equivalent to 195 million full-time workers.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Go behind the numbers:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Working hour losses in upper-middle income countries will top the effects of the 2008 financial crisis.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>81% of the global workforce is currently affected by full or partial workplace closures.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The most at-risk sectors: </strong></span><span>Accommodation and food services, retail, manufacturing, and business and administrative services.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We realize we just leveled a sledgehammer of bad news. Let’s finish this off with ILO Director-General Guy Ryder doing his best Coach Brooks: “The choices we make today will directly affect the way this crisis unfolds and so the lives of billions of people...with the right measures we can limit its impact and the scars it leaves.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>“This is the greatest test for international cooperation in more than 75 years,” Ryder said.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/07/facebook-launches-messaging-app-couples?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Social Network for Two, Please
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="FB's Tuned app" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MTYvZmJfc190dW5lZF9hcHAucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Tuned</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We thought Snapchat began with raunchy intentions, but yesterday Facebook said “hold my eggplant emoji” and quietly launched Tuned, a <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/7/21212139/facebook-tuned-app-relationship-couples-launch?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">messaging app</a> for couples to privately send each other messages, music, photos, and moods. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The app, available in the U.S. and Canada, was a project of the New Product Experimentation team Facebook cobbled together to professionally throw spaghetti at a wall. In less than a year, NPE has released apps including a chat platform to help users make friends, social music listening, a meme-maker, and a dating service for students. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Last fall, Facebook proper also launched a dating service. Tuned comes just in time for the wave of new FB official couples in long-social-distance relationships. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It also syncs with the company's plans to strengthen user connections with close friends and family. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> While Facebook is branding the new app as "a private space" for couples, like the company's main platform Tuned <a href="https://www.theinformation.com/briefings/2e57ed?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">allows for the collection of</a> behavior and communication data to inform ad targeting.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A few weeks ago we wrote the headline “Add @Steve-Mnuchin-7 on Venmo Now” in this newsletter and published an accompanying Instagram post as a joke in reference to the federal government handing out direct payments as part of its stimulus package. We have been informed that a now-deactivated Venmo account was created using that username and the Morning Brew name and logo. It apparently charged accounts for “Coronavirus donations” as part of a fraud scheme. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span class="c-mrkdwn__br" data-stringify-type="paragraph-break"></span>We were completely unaware this account was created and want to make sure our readers know this was not a Morning Brew account or donation drive of any kind. Thanks for understanding.</p>
</td>

The Treasury Department requested an additional $250 billion for the small business loan initiative, citing high demand.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eU.S. markets: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eStocks were up the equivalent of 28–3 most of the day but lost all of those gains before the close. style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nECONOMY\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, PJs\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Economy restart\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MTUvZWNvbm9teV9yZXN0YXJ0LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the middle of a global public health crisis, a leader’s No. 1 goal is to stop the spread of the disease. But as grisly economic numbers stack up and new data indicates infection rates may be leveling off, some governments are also looking for ways to safely restart the economic car. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eKeep in mind, this is like starting a 12-year-old Jag—you have to be very, very careful. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eFirst, in the U.S. \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Saturday, President Trump said he may convene a second coronavirus task force that focuses on how to restart the economy. Then yesterday, top economic advisor Larry Kudlow \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/07/larry-kudlow-coronavirus-small-business-171662?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold Politico\u003c/a\u003e the administration may reopen the economy in the next four to eight weeks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOn Fox News, Kudlow pointed to New York, the U.S. epicenter, where some numbers show the outbreak may be turning a corner.  \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNew deaths in the state had their largest single-day increase yesterday. But infection rates and hospitalizations are hovering around the same level.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHoping to leave his PowerPoint days behind, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has gathered a group of confidants who are reportedly consulting with medical and economic experts to determine how to get New York's rusty gears turning again. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eAcross the Atlantic \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome Vitamin D-deprived governments in Europe are already cracking the door open. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWestern Europe's biggest petroleum-producing nation, Norway, will \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-07/norway-starts-easing-restrictions-as-virus-seen-under-control?sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereopen schools\u003c/a\u003e and universities on April 27. Service businesses that require personal contact will resume gradually. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNorway reacted to the threat of coronavirus early on, and got results. Its new infection rate peaked at 425/day, and that’s been wrestled down to just over 100.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAcross the North Sea, Germany is planning \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/04/06/business/germany-coronavirus-economy/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ea slow economic revival\u003c/a\u003e that would work in tandem with measures to keep the virus from spreading. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e All of this hinges on one key variable: widely available testing, which the U.S. is still behind on. As they get people back to work, governments need the ability to ensure it’s the economy that gets restarted, not the outbreak.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we're here: \u003c/strong\u003eWuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus originated, is now officially \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/07/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eout of lockdown\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" stock. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e It feels like the 1830s, but in fact it was just last October when SoftBank swooped in to rescue WeWork after its spectacularly botched IPO attempt. As part of a larger rescue package, the Japanese conglomerate pledged to buy up to $3 billion in stock from existing employees and investors—including former CEO Adam Neumann. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut SoftBank did not follow through on that pledge, claiming last week that WeWork failed to meet five conditions the deal was premised on. Board rumblings of legal retaliation followed soon after.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eWeWork’s in a tough spot. Its short-term lease system means tenants can walk away at the drop of a tequila shot. And as the coronavirus strikes the economy, \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/78dbfb03-f47d-41f3-9bf6-6696e5ef626b?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethousands reportedly are\u003c/a\u003e, by withholding rent or ending leases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHere's a tongue twister: \u003c/strong\u003eSay \"hydroxychloroquine\" three times. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNow a brain twister:\u003c/strong\u003e President Trump and other high-ranking U.S. officials are \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/0a5ab4f3e9340193b4c7c7c72665cd12?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eencouraging\u003c/a\u003e doctors to use the anti-malaria drug to treat patients with COVID-19...despite warnings from medical leaders. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe drug reportedly hit the president's radar several weeks ago after a Fox News segment detailed its effectiveness in a French trial. Oracle cofounder Larry Ellison and Rudy Giuliani both pushed the president to advocate for hydroxychloroquine, and Giuliani has aggressively championed the drug. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMany are skeptical.\u003c/strong\u003e Infectious disease expert Dr. Anthony Fauci said it's only supported by \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/06/us/politics/coronavirus-trump-malaria-drug.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanecdotal findings\u003c/a\u003e. The American Medical Association’s president said she wouldn't prescribe it over concerns of severe side effects.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe sudden spike in demand is raising \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/07/patients-with-autoimmune-diseases-running-out-of-hydroxychloroquine.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esupply concerns\u003c/a\u003e, especially among patients who take it for autoimmune conditions like lupus and arthritis. Yesterday, India \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/2020/04/07/coronavirus-hydroxychloroquine-trump-india-china/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eeased a ban\u003c/a\u003e on foreign exports of the drug after President Trump threatened to retaliate. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead…\u003c/strong\u003esome doctors are already prescribing COVID-19 patients hydroxychloroquine after the FDA authorized emergency use of the drug last week. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe coronavirus crisis will eliminate 6.7% of working hours globally this quarter, the UN's International Labour Organization (ILO) \u003ca href=\"https://www.ilo.org/global/about-the-ilo/newsroom/news/WCMS_740893/lang--en/index.htm?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eprojects\u003c/a\u003e. That’s equivalent to 195 million full-time workers.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGo behind the numbers:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWorking hour losses in upper-middle income countries will top the effects of the 2008 financial crisis.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e81% of the global workforce is currently affected by full or partial workplace closures.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe most at-risk sectors: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAccommodation and food services, retail, manufacturing, and business and administrative services.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe realize we just leveled a sledgehammer of bad news. Let’s finish this off with ILO Director-General Guy Ryder doing his best Coach Brooks: “The choices we make today will directly affect the way this crisis unfolds and so the lives of billions of people...with the right measures we can limit its impact and the scars it leaves.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003e“This is the greatest test for international cooperation in more than 75 years,” Ryder said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS
